com.helger.jcodemodel

Class JBlock

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.helger.jcodemodel.JBlock
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IJGenerable, IJObject, IJStatement
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    JLambdaBlock

    public class JBlock
extends Object
implements IJGenerable, IJStatement
    A block of Java code, which may contain statements and local declarations.

    JBlock contains a large number of factory methods that creates new statements/declarations. Those newly created statements/declarations are inserted into the "current position". The position advances one every time you add a new instruction.

    • Method Detail

      • virtual

        public boolean virtual()
        Returns:
        true if this is a virtual block never emitting braces or indent. The default is DEFAULT_VIRTUAL_BLOCK

      • virtual

        @Nonnull
public JBlock virtual(boolean bVirtualBlock)
        Mark this block virtual or not. Default is false. Virtual blocks NEVER have braces and are NEVER indented!
        Parameters:
        bVirtualBlock - true to make this block a virtual block.
        Returns:
        this for chaining

      • pos

        @Nonnegative
public int pos()
        Returns:
        the current position to which new statements will be inserted. For example if the value is 0, newly created instructions will be inserted at the very beginning of the block.
        See Also:
        pos(int)

      • pos

        @Nonnegative
public int pos(@Nonnegative
                             int nNewPos)
        Sets the current position.
        Parameters:
        nNewPos - The new position to set
        Returns:
        the old value of the current position.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the new position value is illegal.
        See Also:
        pos()

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Returns:
        true if this block is empty and does not contain any statement.

public int size()
        Returns:

      • insertBefore

        @Nonnull
public JBlock insertBefore(@Nonnull
                                     JVar aVar,
                                     @Nonnull
                                     Object aBefore)
        Insert a variable before another element of this block. This enforces braces and indentation to be enabled!
        Parameters:
        aVar - The variable to be inserted. May not be null.
        aBefore - The object before the variable should be inserted. If the passed object is not contained in this block, an IndexOutOfBoundsException is thrown.
        Returns:
        this for chaining

      • invoke

        public void invoke(@Nonnull
                   IJExpression aExpr,
                   @Nonnull
                   String sMethod)
        Creates an invocation statement and adds it to this block.
        Note: since 3.1.0 this method no longer returns the invocation, to avoid chaining, as this would not work (see #62)
        Parameters:
        aExpr - IJExpression evaluating to the class or object upon which the named method will be invoked
        sMethod - Name of method to invoke

      • invoke

        public void invoke(@Nullable
                   JCodeModel aCM,
                   @Nonnull
                   IJExpression aExpr,
                   @Nonnull
                   String sMethod)
        Creates an invocation statement and adds it to this block.
        Note: since 3.1.0 this method no longer returns the invocation, to avoid chaining, as this would not work (see #62)
        Parameters:
        aCM - CodeModel to use. May be null.
        aExpr - IJExpression evaluating to the class or object upon which the named method will be invoked
        sMethod - Name of method to invoke
        Since:
        3.1.0

      • invokeThis

        public void invokeThis(@Nonnull
                       String sMethod)
        Creates an invocation statement and adds it to this block.
        Note: since 3.1.0 this method no longer returns the invocation, to avoid chaining, as this would not work (see #62)
        Parameters:
        sMethod - Name of method to invoke on this

      • invokeSuper

        public void invokeSuper()
        Explicitly call the super class constructor in this block. This method may only be called as the first call inside a constructor block!
        Note: since 3.1.0 this method no longer returns the invocation, to avoid chaining, as this would not work (see #62)
        Since:
        3.0.1

      • block

        @Nonnull
public JBlock block()
        Create a sub-block and add it to this block. By default braces and indent are required.
        Returns:
        New JBlock
        See Also:
        block(boolean, boolean), blockSimple()

      • blockSimple

        @Nonnull
public JBlock blockSimple()
        Create a sub-block and add it to this block. By default braces and indent are not required.
        Returns:
        New JBlock
        See Also:
        block(), block(boolean, boolean)

      • blockVirtual

        @Nonnull
public JBlock blockVirtual()
        Create a sub-block and add it to this block. This kind of block will never create braces or indent!
        Returns:
        New JBlock
        See Also:
        block(), block(boolean, boolean)

public JBlock block(boolean bBracesRequired,
                              boolean bIndentRequired)
        Create a sub-block and add it to this block
        Parameters:
        bBracesRequired - true if braces should be required
        bIndentRequired - true if indentation is required
        Returns:

                                  AbstractJType aVarType,

                                  IJExpression aCollection)

        Parameters:

        sName - Variable name
        aCollection - Collection to be iterated
        Returns:

        @Nonnull
public JSynchronizedBlock synchronizedBlock(@Nonnull
                                                      IJExpression aExpr)
        Create a synchronized block statement and add it to this block
        Parameters:
        aExpr - The expression to synchronize on. May not be null.
        Returns:
        Newly generated synchronized block. Never null.
        Since:
        2.7.10

      • directStatement

        @Nonnull
public IJStatement directStatement(@Nonnull
                                             String sSource)
        Creates a "literal" statement directly.

        Specified string is printed as-is. This is useful as a short-cut.

        For example, you can invoke this method as: directStatement("a=b+c;").

        Parameters:
        sSource - The source code to state. May not be null.
        Returns:
        The created direct statement.
